person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_022.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
person_022.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

person_213.name: JohnHunter
person_213.description: Leading Scottish surgeon and anatomist who worked in London, holding several major positions. Brother of William Hunter. FRSL.

person_934.name: Jean-Nicolasde la Hire
person_934.description: French doctor and botanist who developed a technique for botanical illustration which has never been fully explained. He was the son of mathemetician and astronomer Philippe de la Hire.

person_021.name: StephenHales
person_021.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

person_240.name: ErasmusDarwin
person_240.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

person_024.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
person_024.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_227.name: JeanSenebier
person_227.description: Genevan naturalist; pioneer in field of photosynthesis.

person_348.name: JanIngenhousz
person_348.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

person_051.name: JohnPringle
person_051.description: Physician who served as President of the Royal Society of London, 1772-1778. Created a baronet. FRSL.

person_163.name: Thomas CharlesHope
person_163.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_937.name: JohnJay
person_937.description: American statesman, patriot, diplomat, abolitionist, signatory of the Treaty of Paris, and a Founding Father of the United States. Davy quotes him as the author of a letter on a species of apple with one sweet and one sour side.

person_936.name: Henry VIII
person_936.description: King of England from 22 April 1509 until his death in 1547.

place_323.name: Cambridge
place_323.description: Cambridge is the county town of Cambridgeshire.

place_990.name: Siberia
place_990.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

otherwork_072.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_072.author: Miller and William Watson

otherwork_262.name: A Discourse on the Different Kinds of Air, Delivered at the Anniversary Meeting of the Royal Society
otherwork_262.author: John Pringle

otherwork_263.name: Communications to the Board of Agriculture; on subjects relative to the husbandry, and internal improvement of the country.
otherwork_263.author: John Jay
